comments.commentBody: LIttle did he know that this was going to be publicized in the way it is. Precisely why he should have behaved more genteelly. We have no way of knowing how our behavior will ripple outward, and in many circumstances should stay aware of the fact that it can.
If it's not Zenyatta, it damn well better be Goldikova.

Congratulations to Team Zenyatta!!  And thank you to the voters who voted for Zenyatta, racing's brightest star, to be Horse of the Year.  This vote has given me hope that horse racing has not lost sight of what invigorates and inspires racing fans to follow this sport.  It is fitting that Queen Z has been awarded her well deserved crown.  I do think she meets and transcends the traditional measures of greatness.
Zenyatta.  Not even close.

I have used a Mac since the winter of 1984/5. I have worked at Microtech International in New Haven where we OEM'd hard drives for (among others) Macs and NeXT computers. I am writing this at midnight on a battered old-style all-plastic MacBook, on which I'm finishing up self-publishing in Adobe InDesign CS5 my own book for an Amazon.com subsidiary. If Steve Jobs ever reads this, I hope he is drinking a Pepsi at the time, and remembering the early days when he had to ask John Sculley if he wanted to sell sugar-water forever, or wanted to choose transform the future, instead -- with Apple. Get well, Steve.

I think many dogs are as capable as Chaser or Rico; we just don't usually bother to teach them or notice how much they have learned. Tansy my late golden retriever frequently surprised us, in her later years, with her obvious understanding of conversation not directed at her. She plainly had acquired a large recognition vocabulary of English words. How large? She was a pet, not a research subject, so we never bothered to figure that out. But after living with Tansy, it's no surprise to me that a systematically taught Border Collie can learn 1,000 proper nouns.
I think that the better comparison might be to adults (especially older adults) trying to learn a foreign language. My struggles trying to learn German came to mind as I read this article!

Great article.  Specific to language, we've noticed that our dogs know context.  "Out" can mean "do you want to go outside" or "get out of the kitchen."  None of our dogs have ever confused the two.  Goes back to picking up the non-verbal cues.  Regarding "get out of the kitchen," every single dog has always understood that it meant "no paws on the linoleum" until we said the magic word - "okay."  Again, that "okay" could have been in a conversation, and not directed at the dogs, but the dogs were listening for it...

As an ex a dog handler who worked with a team of high security guard dogs, I would like to point out that the standard tests used to study animal cognition and/or language, [for example the studies indicated and also the so called "mirror tests",] suffer a fundamental flaw or bias in that they assume that the uniquely human perspective is the only measurably condition.

For example dogs do not use vision as a primary sense and as a result the "mirror test" has an inbuilt negative bias. Anecdotally, one of my dogs had a pair of sunglasses; the first time he wore them, he had the expected doggy reaction and flipped them off. This continued until he saw his reflection in a shop window, then his body language became: "hmmm...", "cool...", "really scary". And yes, I would say that he did recognize the shop window as a mirror since, when young, he would tense into a guard position at his reflection but with experience, he would ignore these mirrors.

Similarly, with language, the assumption is that language is both human and vocal. But dogs are pack animals who communicate by a combination of "body language", "scent marking" and "dance" with vocal communication being very low on the list. Part of the job of handling guard dogs is being able to read this "doggy language", and again anecdotally, when one of my dogs was separated from the rest of the team for a solo adventure I would be able to follow much of the "doggy conversation" on our return.

Another relevant anecdote is that dogs tell fibs; when we would return from a visit to the vets, the brave guard dog fearlessly standing up to the sadistic veterinarian as recounted to the rest of the pack was pure fantasy.

Finally, my last word on the sunglasses: In his old age,the guard dog who wore the sunglasses would spend many hours at the beach with slightly damp fur sitting on a high rock exposed to the "Mistral" contentedly waring his sunglasses.

I wonder how well humans would do if Chaser "barked" the same commands to us? We often overlook that aspect of animal intelligence. Most of us couldn't do it if it wasn't in our own language. Now imagine commands  coming from an entirely different species, with different vocal chords and sounds? I believe animals are as intelligent in their own way, as the people who are testing them. Anyone who has ever owned a "smart" dog can attest to this, they understand far more than we ever want to admit.
Can you imagine the development of a kid if at least one of his parents give him/her the same attention ? Thanks Dr Pilley for your passionate work, now we all have something to learn from a dog.

I am so pleased that Dr. Pilley documented the training of his Border Collie. I try to share with friends and family the intelligence of my Australian Shepherd, a herding dog similar to the Border Collie. When she was three, I prepared a note for a friend who was going to watch her for a few days. The friend laughed about the detail of it; I had written down the commands that Toko knew at that point - which turned out to be about 200 then.

Over the nine years since, Toko's understanding and interaction with me verbally has increased but most interesting is that she keeps changing and improving the way SHE communicates with me. She develops - without any input from me - different whines and murmurs and barks for the different things she needs. I am trained and continuously receive updated training by her. She is a fantastically brilliant and loving companion.

Aussies are working dogs who need jobs and physical activity but I would say that they are a bit less intense and physically demanding than the Border Collie. Mine seems to make up for having a suburban life (she does get to play frisbee, go skiing and boating, etc.) by honing her intellectual skills.

Certainly our pets, other domesticated animals and wild animals have great intelligence that we do not often give them credit for. Ever watch a family of Canadian Geese?

Last sentence is most interesting: "Dr. Horowitz agreed: “It is not necessarily Chaser or Rico who is exceptional; it is the attention that is lavished on them,” she said."

How many species of nonhuman animals would display stunningly more intelligence than we anticipate if they were raised in such a way that that intellect was fostered? Most are raised in conditions of severe intellectual and educational deprivation - and yet it is often our perception of animals' lack of intelligence that is the basis for our feeling we have a right to use them for food and other ends.

Our 11-year-old Labrador has a remarkable ability to understand language. But it is not only his grasp of spoken words (including some spelled words), but his ability to somehow intuit what is happening that is amazing. It is as if he has the ability to read our minds at times. I believe he (and perhaps all dogs) have ways to communicate that humans do not. Probably there is some sense, such as smell, we humans do not notice, that enables him to wake from a deep sleep in another room when I merely think of going for a walk. His language and 'mind-reading' skills have also increased with his age.

Very interesting article. I kept a Border Collie for many years, and her pup, mixed with a hunting dog, was the best dog I have ever raised.

But please take better care of our English language, so our dogs learn it properly, to wit, "Border collies are working dogs. They have a reputation for *smartness*...."

Enexpected?  Anyone who has a close relationship with a dog knows that dogs can acquire a working knowledge of any language unlike mono-lingual societies.  Why is there always a sense of surprise when it comes to non-human sentient beings?  And, they can sniff bombs, diseases, threatenting individuals, and the needs of physically challenged individuals.  As far as I can tell, they nearly have it all over the rest of their human counterparts -- and they are generally much nicer too!

Didn't BF Skinner teach pigeons how to read, identify paintings, and what not?

Don't see how this is a huge break through.
Man's continual journey is discovering he is not special.

I wish I had time to read all the reader responses. My interest focuses on what would motivate an animal to perform like this for human beings. They don't do it for themselves, so what is really behind the capacities under discussion, and how can that be made relevant to what we human beings hope to learn about ourselves and the biological context in which we exist?

It appears that the animals are motivated by the desire to please us. It can't all be for some tasty treat. The article touched, ever so lightly, on a comparison between the animals' drive to learn and perform with young human beings. It seems that the interest in what motivates learning and performance of learned material needs more study.
Wishing you & your family all the best, with love.

Chaser is one awesome dog! I can't wait to introduce him to Nellie on February 9th!
My border collie, Nellie knows basic functional words. Since she cannot herd sheep,she spends a good part of the day hunting the cat.I can ask her "where's he kitty?" or find the squirrel". Does that count as a recognizing syntax? I think I'll try the new language learning method on my high school students in my French class.

I wish Mr. Job's well and truly hope that he will survive this setback.  If he does, I hope that he'll use his time left on this earth to help those without the resources that he has to try to change our healthcare system.  Since he's a technological genius, I hope he uses the rest of his limited time to join forces with the U.S. government and completely overhaul our outdated, archaic system.  I know that, if he survives, his entire mindset will change for the better... and "greater good of society" - and not for the profit of the very few...

Anyone who has ever had a dog or a cat knows of the deep, limitless communication that can occur between animals and people.

With love, no words----all words----are possible.
Clearly, Chaser is not remembering all these names.  She's reading the names written on the toys in indelible marker by the good Doctor.

comments.commentBody: The well-trained Border Collie responds to verbal command and the whistle. There are many commands. It takes real talent to train the BC. Once a herd is 'broke' to the BC, the dog can load them on to a trailer or place them in a loading pen - with ease. The BC will not protect sheep. That task falls to a different sort of dog - of which there are many.
